column2: I--THE CURE FOR LOVE
column3: I-THE CURE FOR LOVE

column2: The excellent Mr. Morris was an Englishman, and he lived in the days of Queen Victoria the Good.
column3: The excellent mr Morris was an Englishman, and he lived in the days of Queen Victoria the Good.

column2: He was a prosperous and very sensible man; he read the _Times_ and went to church, and as he grew towards middle age an expression of quiet contented contempt for all who were not as himself settled on his face.
column3: He was a prosperous and very sensible man; he read the underscore Times underscore and went to church, and as he grew towards middle age an expression of quiet contented contempt for all who were not as himself settled on his face.

column2: He was one of those people who do everything that is right and proper and sensible with inevitable regularity.
column3: He was one of those people who do everything that is right and proper and sensible with inevitable regularity.

column2: He always wore just the right and proper clothes, steering the narrow way between the smart and the shabby, always subscribed to the right charities, just the judicious compromise between ostentation and meanness, and never failed to have his hair cut to exactly the proper length.
column3: He always wore just the right and proper clothes, steering the narrow way between the smart and the shabby, always subscribed to the right charities, just the judicious compromise between ostentation and meanness, and never failed to have his hair cut to exactly the proper length.

column2: Everything that it was right and proper for a man in his position to possess, he possessed; and everything that it was not right and proper for a man in his position to possess, he did not possess.
column3: Everything that it was right and proper for a man in his position to possess, he possessed; and everything that it was not right and proper for a man in his position to possess, he did not possess.

column2: And among other right and proper possessions, this Mr. Morris had a wife and children.
column3: And among other right and proper possessions, this mr Morris had a wife and children.

column2: They were the right sort of wife, and the right sort and number of children, of course; nothing imaginative or highty-flighty about any of them, so far as Mr. Morris could see; they wore perfectly correct clothing, neither smart nor hygienic nor faddy in any way, but just sensible; and they lived in a nice sensible house in the later Victorian sham Queen Anne style of architecture, with sham half-timbering of chocolate-painted plaster in the gables, Lincrusta Walton sham carved oak panels, a terrace of terra cotta to imitate stone, and cathedral glass in the front door.
column3: They were the right sort of wife, and the right sort and number of children, of course; nothing imaginative or highty flighty about any of them, so far as mr Morris could see; they wore perfectly correct clothing, neither smart nor hygienic nor faddy in any way, but just sensible; and they lived in a nice sensible house in the later Victorian sham Queen Anne style of architecture, with sham half timbering of chocolate painted plaster in the gables, Lincrusta Walton sham carved oak panels, a terrace of terra cotta to imitate stone, and cathedral glass in the front door.

column2: His boys went to good solid schools, and were put to respectable professions; his girls, in spite of a fantastic protest or so, were all married to suitable, steady, oldish young men with good prospects.
column3: His boys went to good solid schools, and were put to respectable professions; his girls, in spite of a fantastic protest or so, were all married to suitable, steady, oldish young men with good prospects.

column2: And when it was a fit and proper thing for him to do so, Mr. Morris died.
column3: And when it was a fit and proper thing for him to do so, mr Morris died.

column2: His tomb was of marble, and, without any art nonsense or laudatory inscription, quietly imposing--such being the fashion of his time.
column3: His tomb was of marble, and, without any art nonsense or laudatory inscription, quietly imposing-such being the fashion of his time.

column2: He underwent various changes according to the accepted custom in these cases, and long before this story begins his bones even had become dust, and were scattered to the four quarters of heaven.
column3: He underwent various changes according to the accepted custom in these cases, and long before this story begins his bones even had become dust, and were scattered to the four quarters of heaven.

column2: And his sons and his grandsons and his great-grandsons and his great-great-grandsons, they too were dust and ashes, and were scattered likewise.
column3: And his sons and his grandsons and his great grandsons and his great great grandsons, they too were dust and ashes, and were scattered likewise.

column2: It was a thing he could not have imagined, that a day would come when even his great-great-grandsons would be scattered to the four winds of heaven.
column3: It was a thing he could not have imagined, that a day would come when even his great great grandsons would be scattered to the four winds of heaven.

column2: If any one had suggested it to him he would have resented it.
column3: If any one had suggested it to him he would have resented it.

column2: He was one of those worthy people who take no interest in the future of mankind at all.
column3: He was one of those worthy people who take no interest in the future of mankind at all.

column2: He had grave doubts, indeed, if there was any future for mankind after he was dead.
column3: He had grave doubts, indeed, if there was any future for mankind after he was dead.

column2: It seemed quite impossible and quite uninteresting to imagine anything happening after he was dead.
column3: It seemed quite impossible and quite uninteresting to imagine anything happening after he was dead.

column2: Yet the thing was so, and when even his great-great-grandson was dead and decayed and forgotten, when the sham half-timbered house had gone the way of all shams, and the _Times_ was extinct, and the silk hat a ridiculous antiquity, and the modestly imposing stone that had been sacred to Mr. Morris had been burnt to make lime for mortar, and all that Mr. Morris had found real and important was sere and dead, the world was still going on, and people were still going about it, just as heedless and impatient of the Future, or, indeed, of anything but their own selves and property, as Mr. Morris had been.
column3: Yet the thing was so, and when even his great great grandson was dead and decayed and forgotten, when the sham half timbered house had gone the way of all shams, and the underscore Times underscore was extinct, and the silk hat a ridiculous antiquity, and the modestly imposing stone that had been sacred to mr Morris had been burnt to make lime for mortar, and all that mr Morris had found real and important was sere and dead, the world was still going on, and people were still going about it, just as heedless and impatient of the Future, or, indeed, of anything but their own selves and property, as mr Morris had been.

column2: And, strange to tell, and much as Mr. Morris would have been angered if any one had foreshadowed it to him, all over the world there were scattered a multitude of people, filled with the breath of life, in whose veins the blood of Mr. Morris flowed.
column3: And, strange to tell, and much as mr Morris would have been angered if any one had foreshadowed it to him, all over the world there were scattered a multitude of people, filled with the breath of life, in whose veins the blood of mr Morris flowed.

column2: Just as some day the life which is gathered now in the reader of this very story may also be scattered far and wide about this world, and mingled with a thousand alien strains, beyond all thought and tracing.
column3: Just as some day the life which is gathered now in the reader of this very story may also be scattered far and wide about this world, and mingled with a thousand alien strains, beyond all thought and tracing.

column2: And among the descendants of this Mr. Morris was one almost as sensible and clear-headed as his ancestor.
column3: And among the descendants of this mr Morris was one almost as sensible and clear headed as his ancestor.

column2: He had just the same stout, short frame as that ancient man of the nineteenth century, from whom his name of Morris--he spelt it Mwres--came; he had the same half-contemptuous expression of face.
column3: He had just the same stout, short frame as that ancient man of the nineteenth century, from whom his name of Morris-he spelt it m w r e's-came; he had the same half contemptuous expression of face.

column2: He was a prosperous person, too, as times went, and he disliked the "new-fangled," and bothers about the future and the lower classes, just as much as the ancestral Morris had done.
column3: He was a prosperous person, too, as times went, and he disliked the "new fangled," and bothers about the future and the lower classes, just as much as the ancestral Morris had done.

column2: He did not read the _Times_: indeed, he did not know there ever had been a _Times_--that institution had foundered somewhere in the intervening gulf of years; but the phonograph machine, that talked to him as he made his toilet of a morning, might have been the voice of a reincarnated Blowitz when it dealt with the world's affairs.
column3: He did not read the underscore Times underscore: indeed, he did not know there ever had been a underscore Times underscore--that institution had foundered somewhere in the intervening gulf of years; but the phonograph machine, that talked to him as he made his toilet of a morning, might have been the voice of a reincarnated Blowitz when it dealt with the world's affairs.

column2: This phonographic machine was the size and shape of a Dutch clock, and down the front of it were electric barometric indicators, and an electric clock and calendar, and automatic engagement reminders, and where the clock would have been was the mouth of a trumpet.
column3: This phonographic machine was the size and shape of a Dutch clock, and down the front of it were electric barometric indicators, and an electric clock and calendar, and automatic engagement reminders, and where the clock would have been was the mouth of a trumpet.

column2: When it had news the trumpet gobbled like a turkey, "Galloop, galloop," and then brayed out its message as, let us say, a trumpet might bray.
column3: When it had news the trumpet gobbled like a turkey, "Galloop, galloop," and then brayed out its message as, let us say, a trumpet might bray.

column2: It would tell Mwres in full, rich, throaty tones about the overnight accidents to the omnibus flying-machines that plied around the world, the latest arrivals at the fashionable resorts in Tibet, and of all the great monopolist company meetings of the day before, while he was dressing.
column3: It would tell m w r e's in full, rich, throaty tones about the overnight accidents to the omnibus flying machines that plied around the world, the latest arrivals at the fashionable resorts in Tibet, and of all the great monopolist company meetings of the day before, while he was dressing.

column2: If Mwres did not like hearing what it said, he had only to touch a stud, and it would choke a little and talk about something else.
column3: If m w r e's did not like hearing what it said, he had only to touch a stud, and it would choke a little and talk about something else.

column2: Of course his toilet differed very much from that of his ancestor.
column3: Of course his toilet differed very much from that of his ancestor.

column2: It is doubtful which would have been the more shocked and pained to find himself in the clothing of the other.
column3: It is doubtful which would have been the more shocked and pained to find himself in the clothing of the other.

column2: Mwres would certainly have sooner gone forth to the world stark naked than in the silk hat, frock coat, grey trousers and watch-chain that had filled Mr. Morris with sombre self-respect in the past.
column3: m w r e's would certainly have sooner gone forth to the world stark naked than in the silk hat, frock coat, grey trousers and watch chain that had filled mr Morris with sombre self respect in the past.

column2: For Mwres there was no shaving to do: a skilful operator had long ago removed every hair-root from his face.
column3: For m w r e's there was no shaving to do: a skilful operator had long ago removed every hair root from his face.

column2: His legs he encased in pleasant pink and amber garments of an air-tight material, which with the help of an ingenious little pump he distended so as to suggest enormous muscles.
column3: His legs he encased in pleasant pink and amber garments of an air tight material, which with the help of an ingenious little pump he distended so as to suggest enormous muscles.

column2: Above this he also wore pneumatic garments beneath an amber silk tunic, so that he was clothed in air and admirably protected against sudden extremes of heat or cold.
column3: Above this he also wore pneumatic garments beneath an amber silk tunic, so that he was clothed in air and admirably protected against sudden extremes of heat or cold.

column2: Over this he flung a scarlet cloak with its edge fantastically curved.
column3: Over this he flung a scarlet cloak with its edge fantastically curved.

column2: On his head, which had been skilfully deprived of every scrap of hair, he adjusted a pleasant little cap of bright scarlet, held on by suction and inflated with hydrogen, and curiously like the comb of a cock.
column3: On his head, which had been skilfully deprived of every scrap of hair, he adjusted a pleasant little cap of bright scarlet, held on by suction and inflated with hydrogen, and curiously like the comb of a cock.

column2: So his toilet was complete; and, conscious of being soberly and becomingly attired, he was ready to face his fellow-beings with a tranquil eye.
column3: So his toilet was complete; and, conscious of being soberly and becomingly attired, he was ready to face his fellow beings with a tranquil eye.

column2: This Mwres--the civility of "Mr." had vanished ages ago--was one of the officials under the Wind Vane and Waterfall Trust, the great company that owned every wind wheel and waterfall in the world, and which pumped all the water and supplied all the electric energy that people in these latter days required.

column2: He lived in a vast hotel near that part of London called Seventh Way, and had very large and comfortable apartments on the seventeenth floor.

column2: Households and family life had long since disappeared with the progressive refinement of manners; and indeed the steady rise in rents and land values, the disappearance of domestic servants, the elaboration of cookery, had rendered the separate domicile of Victorian times impossible, even had any one desired such a savage seclusion.

column2: It was a very different meal from a Victorian breakfast.
column3: It was a very different meal from a Victorian breakfast.

column2: The rude masses of bread needing to be carved and smeared over with animal fat before they could be made palatable, the still recognisable fragments of recently killed animals, hideously charred and hacked, the eggs torn ruthlessly from beneath some protesting hen,--such things as these, though they constituted the ordinary fare of Victorian times, would have awakened only horror and disgust in the refined minds of the people of these latter days.
